{{Infobox person | name = Ursula Koch | image = Ursula Koch.jpg | caption = Ursula Koch (before 1999) | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|7|1|df=y}} | birth_place = Zürich | death_date = | death_place = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = Swiss | other_names = Ursula Koch-Pomeranz | education = Ph.D. in organic chemistry | alma_mater = University of Zürich | occupation = Former Swiss politician, | notable works = | style = | yearsactive = 1979–2000 | known_for = ''Zürich ist gebaut!'' | notable_works = | awards = | spouse = | website = }}'''Ursula Koch''' (1 July 1941 in [[Zürich]], citizen of Zürich) is a former Swiss politician, and was the first women president of the [[Social Democratic Party of Switzerland]] (SP).
== Early life== Born and raised in Zürich, Ursula Koch attended ''Sekundarschule'' in the [[Municipalities in the canton of Zürich|municipality]] of [[Stäfa]] on ''Zürichsee'' lake shore. Thereafter she worked as a domestic helper in Lausanne, the so-called ''Welschlandjahr'' which at that time usually teenage women absolved in western Switzerland (''Welschland'') to improve the knowledge of the French language. She graduated at the teacher training college in Zürich, and absolved in 1962 an exchange year at the [[University of Oregon]], Eugene, Oregon. In 1963 Ursula Koch started to study natural sciences at the [[University of Zürich]] and graduated at the Institute of [[Organic Chemistry]], where she worked as a research assistant from 1970 to 1976.<ref name="munzinger">{{cite web|url=http://www.munzinger.de/search/go/document.jsp?id=00000022250|title=Ursula Koch|publisher=Internationales Biographisches Archiv 04/2001|author=|language=German|date=2001-01-15|accessdate=2014-12-18}}</ref> Ursula Koch promoted as ''Dr. phil. II'' in 1976.<ref name="swissinfo">{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/ger/sp-praesidentin-ursula-koch-zurueckgetreten/1463338|title=SP-Präsidentin Ursula Koch zurückgetreten|publisher=swissinfo.ch|author=|language=German|date=2000-04-15|accessdate=2014-11-28}}</ref>
== Political career == === Kantonsrat and Stadtrat Zürich === As member of the Cantonal Council (''Kantonsrat''),<ref name="staatsarchiv-zh">{{cite web|url=http://suche.staatsarchiv.djiktzh.ch/resultatliste.aspx|title=Results on search for "Kantonsrätin Dr. Ursula Koch"|publisher=[[Staatsarchiv Zürich]]|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2014-12-18}}</ref> the legislative assembly of the canton of Zürich, for the ''SP'' of the canton of Zürich, Ursula Koch refused, as dedicated woman's politician, the traditional male-oriented oath to the ''Vaterland'' and instead pledged allegiance on the ''Mutterland'' of office in 1979,<ref name="weltwoche">{{cite web|url=http://www.weltwoche.ch/ausgaben/2007-30/artikel-2007-30-amtseid-aufs-mut.html|title=Amtseid aufs «Mutterland»|publisher=Die Weltwoche 30/2007|author=Daniela Niederberger|language=German|date=2007|accessdate=2014-12-18}}</ref> but was re-elected until 1986.<ref name="swissinfo"/>
Beginning in 1986, Ursula Koch was voted as member of the Zürich City Councillor (''Stadtrat''), the executive board of the city of Zürich. She acted as superintendent of the engineering department (''Bauamt II'' or ''Hochbaudepartment''), i.e. Ursula Koch was responsible for all building construction works in Zürich until 1998. Ursula Koch opposed intensively the opening of the former industrial zones for the construction of more commerce buildings, in favor of more accommodation buildings at moderate prizes; therefore her statement "City (of Zürich) is built" (in Swiss-German: ''Die Stadt ist gebaut!'') on 16 March 1988 to the members of the SIA association,<ref>SIA, in German: ''Schweizerischer Ingenieur- und Architektenverein'', literally: Association of the Swiss engineers and architects.</ref> the parent organization of Swiss engineers and architects, became her best-known saying.<ref name="spzh">{{cite web|url=http://www.sp-zuerich.ch/node/815|title="Zürich ist gebaut" — ein Zitat mit Eigenleben|publisher=SP Zürich|author=Mirella Wepf|language=German|date=2011-09-01|accessdate=2014-11-27}}</ref>
At the 1999 national Council elections, Ursula Koch reached with 122,846 votes the second best result in Switzerland. Despite the top result, the inner-party disputes not declined.<ref name="swissinfo"/> As ''Nationalrätin'' for the SP party, Ursula Koch was voted by the citizens of the canton Zürich as member of the [[National Council (Switzerland)|''Nationalrat'']], the Swiss lower parliament's house, from 6 December 1999 to 10 May 2000, when she resigned for reasons of health.<ref name="swissinfo"/>
=== President of the Social Democratic Party of Switzerland (SP) === On 28 June 1997 Ursula Koch was elected by the members of the SP Switzerland at an extraordinary party congress in Thun, and won, despite lack of political experience at the national level, against Andrea Hämmerle, and succeeded the popular but controversy longyear SP president Peter Bodenmann.<ref name="swissinfo"/> From 1997 to April 2000, Ursula Koch was the president of the ''SP'',<ref name="hds-sps">{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D17393.php|title=Sozialdemokratische Partei (SP)|publisher=HDS|author=Bernard Degen|language=German|date=2013-01-24|accessdate=2014-11-27}}</ref> even being the first women president of the national section of the Swiss social democratic party (SP).
After her election as president of the party, Ursula Koch encountered massive rejection of their person, according to own information, and the conflict took place increasingly via media reaching its first peak in March 1998, when the general secretary Barbara Häring resigned. Party colleagues of the so-called "Bodenmann-Clan" (named after the previous party president) criticized an increasing lack of concept and the absence of the SP in the Swiss political arena. The crisis culminated after a closed-door meeting of the SP executive board on 19 February 2000: the reconciliation within the party leadership did not materialise, and on 15 April Ursula Koch retired by the party leadership and from the parliament due to health reasons.<ref name="swissinfo"/><ref name="srf-tagesschau">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/tagesschau/video/ursula-koch-nachbeben?id=74b40d85-5d86-4434-9a64-ee04433911a4|title=Ursula Koch: Nachbeben|publisher=''Tagesschau'', Swiss television SRF 1|author=|language=German|date=2000-04-15|accessdate=2014-11-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230013509/http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/tagesschau/video/ursula-koch-nachbeben?id=74b40d85-5d86-4434-9a64-ee04433911a4|archive-date=2014-12-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
As president of the political party ''SP'', and therefore member of the so-called [[Elefantenrunde#Switzerland|''Elefantenrunde'']] – meaning the presidents of the five most 'important' political parties in Switzerland – Ursula Koch participated at the first [[Streaming media|live stream]] broadcast from the [[Federal Palace of Switzerland]] (''Bundeshaus'') in late 1999.<ref name="20min-1999">{{cite web|url=http://www.20min.ch/digital/news/story/Das-hatte-die-Technikwelt-1999-zu-bieten-29265078#showid=115360&index=8|title=Das hatte die Technikwelt 1999 zu bieten|publisher=[[20 Minuten]]|author=|language=German|date=2014-12-12|accessdate=2014-12-12}}</ref><ref name="webtv">{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.ch/e/sessionen/webtvlive/Pages/default.aspx|title=WebTV Live+|publisher=The Federal Assembly - The Swiss Parliament|author=|language=|date=|accessdate=2014-12-12}}</ref>
Since 2000, she is no more charged in a political office, and in November 2000 Ursula Koch married her long-time life partner.<ref name="schweizaktuell-20130906">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/schweiz-aktuell/video/wo-ist-ursula-koch?id=86607819-3bd8-4222-8f38-9b431924c015|title=Wo ist Ursula Koch?|publisher=[[Schweiz aktuell]]|author=|language=German|date=2013-09-06|accessdate=2014-11-27}}</ref>
